To slow the spread of COVID-19, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), 34 in conjunction with state and local governments, has implemented social distancing and 35 quarantine rules.
[43] The CDC has also recommended changing outpatient practice patterns.

Specifically, they advise to "reduce unnecessary healthcare visits" and "explore alternatives to 37 face-to-face triage and visits." [15] A major challenge during this crisis is to keep patients and 38 the healthcare team safely distant while providing patients with effective and efficient care.
Telemedicine is a logical solution to help address this challenge.

Orthopaedic surgeons who primarily perform total joint arthroplasty (TJA) of the hip and 41 knee treat a predominantly outpatient population that is at high risk for complications and death 42 from 44, 54] Most patients of adult reconstruction clinics are older than 60 years, 43 and many have comorbidities that put them at high risk of contracting severe acute respiratory 44 syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) if exposed.

[65] Therefore, an effective and efficient 45 TJA telemedicine practice may enable providers to continue delivering care while preventing 46 unnecessary exposure of at-risk patients to the outpatient clinic during this pandemic.

Providers cite poor information technology (IT) platform design and 50 "information overload" with regard to the chosen system as barriers to use. The benefits of telemedicine are considerable, especially when access to in-person clinical care is 289 limited, such as during a natural disaster or pandemic. Telemedicine can lower healthcare costs 290 and improve access to care, especially for patients in rural or underserved areas. In appropriately 291 selected patients, telemedicine produces similar outcomes to those of in-person visits. During 292 crises such as the COVID-19 pandemic, when healthcare access is limited and mobility is 293 impaired, telemedicine allows providers to continue delivering quality patient care while 294 avoiding unnecessary risks to themselves, the care team, and their patients.

[56] Synchronous vs. Asynchronous Telemedicine 104 Care via telemedicine can be synchronous or asynchronous. Each mode has different IT 105 infrastructure requirements. Synchronous telemedicine involves virtual encounters that occur in 106 real time, [4, 38] typically involving one-on-one meetings using webcam-enabled 107 teleconferencing. Alternately, telephone-only visits can be conducted. Synchronous sessions 108 should be used when discussion is needed, such as during new patient consultations, preoperative 109 counseling, postoperative evaluations, and follow-up visits. 110 Asynchronous (i.e., "store-and-forward") telemedicine involves the gathering, 111 summarizing, storing, and sharing of data for a patient or, more often, another provider to review 112 at a later time. [4] Medical record annotation, email, and recorded video messages are means of 113 asynchronous telemedicine, [38] which is ideal for educating patients outside of an encounter.

FIGREF6.text: Insufficient training and unfamiliarity with the technology are major barriers to adoption and 151 application of telemedicine.[22, 26]  In response to the growing utility and complexity of152 telemedicine, medical education curricula have begun integrating telemedicine training concepts 153 early during medical training, which may increase trainees' familiarity with telemedicine 154 systems in the future. [19] 155 One approach to streamlining the training process is to focus first on training 156 "communities of practice," meaning groups of employees who work in the same care setting, 157 managing the same patients. A community of practice may include medical office coordinators, 158 medical assistants, nurses, advanced practice providers, and physicians. This approach is 159 effective in workplace training because it increases the group's comfort with and knowledge of 160 the technology. [9, 46, 58] Important considerations during training are data and information 161 sharing and collaboration between the communities of practice. [19] 162 Given the limited use of telemedicine among TJA providers, it is typically necessary to 163 train them not only on the technology but also on the business and interpersonal aspects of 164 managing a telemedicine practice and caring for patients remotely. Slovensky et. al. [53] 165 proposed that training should include skills related to digital communication, technology literacy, 166 business and billing, regulatory and compliance issues, and deploying products and services. 167 Because these factors are integral to managing a traditional TJA practice (without telemedicine), 168 TJA providers may be well prepared for the transition to delivering safe, effective, and compliant 169 care via telemedicine. FIGREF7.text: 175use include the costs of implementation and the lack of reimbursement for telemedicine.[51]    176 Before the modifications of Medicare and Medicaid rules during the current pandemic,177 government-funded insurance plans had various approaches to reimbursing physicians for 178 telemedicine. Under Medicare Part B, physician reimbursement for telemedicine services was 179 strictly regulated. Requirements for reimbursement included that the patient be located in a 180 designated "rural health professional shortage area," a county not part of metropolitan area, or a 181 facility participating in a Federal Telemedicine Demonstration Project. [60] Low-resource or 182 underfunded institutions outside such areas did not qualify for telemedicine reimbursement. [29] 183 These limitations prevented the use of telemedicine for most patients. In contrast, the Veterans 184 Health Administration operates the nation's largest telemedicine program and offers free 185 telemedicine to all patients enrolled in their insurance program. [62] Medicaid reimbursement for 186 telemedicine varies by state, with some states providing full reimbursement with no restrictions, 187 and others imposing restrictions similar to those of Medicare. [30, 39] Private insurers have 188 various reimbursement plans, based on local coverage determinations for a given payer. State 189 mandates for private insurance reimbursement for telemedicine services, in some cases 190 irrespective of rural or non-rural setting, have resulted in expansion of telemedicine coverage. response to the COVID-19 pandemic and in accordance with CDC guidance, many 193 practices have implemented telemedicine to avoid in-person contact between providers and patients. Federal and state reimbursement laws have evolved rapidly to accommodate this change, with the most liberating adjustments coming through the Coronavirus Preparedness and 196 Response Supplemental Appropriations Act, which was passed on March 6, 2020. This act has 197 provided emergency funding, estimated at $500 million, resulting in expanded reimbursement 198 for all telemedicine services provided to Medicare patients, regardless of originating site, during 199 the pandemic. The act gives states the option to suspend interstate licensure requirements that 200 had hampered the delivery of telemedicine across state lines. [1, 55] Additionally, the expansion 201 allows TJA providers to evaluate and treat patients on the basis of history and discussion when it 202 is impractical to perform a physical examination. [59] 203 Also in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, Health Insurance Portability and 204 Accountability Act (HIPAA) regulations have been relaxed. [59] The primary goal of the HHS 205 during this emergency is to enable the provision of quality care to patients regardless of location.206HHS acknowledges that compliance with HIPAA regulations may not always be possible during 207 telemedicine delivery. Thus, the HHS and the Office of Civil Rights have exercised their 208 discretionary authority to decline prosecution for HIPAA compliance violations that occur 209 during "good-faith" efforts to provide patient care during the pandemic.

These requirements vary by state; therefore, practice 215 leaders should consult legal and compliance advisors before creating or continuing their 216 telemedicine practices to confirm ongoing compliance.[2, 10, 14]  During the pandemic, regulatory changes have evolved rapidly, and practice managers and providers should update 218 their understanding of these changes on a daily basis.219 220 Feasibility of Telemedicine in a TJA Practice 221 TJA patients in several stages of evaluation are appropriate for telemedicine encounters. For 222 patient counseling and education, as well as imaging review, remote synchronous video 223 encounters appear to be equivalent to in-person visits. However, because of the need for hands-224 on patient care and in-office procedures, traditional clinic visits cannot be replaced entirely in 225 TJA practices. 226 Given the current pandemic, our department rapidly implemented a telemedicine TJA 227 clinic to treat all patients except those deemed to require in-person evaluation. In-person visits 228 were limited to first postoperative visits and urgent care needs that could not be managed 229 remotely; otherwise, all patients capable of doing so were evaluated via telemedicine. 230 Telemedicine was used for new patients, as well as established patients. The range of topics 231 addressed at these visits included nonoperative treatment options, preoperative counseling, 232 imaging review, acute concerns not requiring in-person evaluation, routine postoperative follow-233 up, and long-term surveillance. The patient education typically provided before TJA can also be 234 accomplished through interactive telemedicine. [57] Thomas et al [57] reported practical tips to 235 improve the telemedicine patient-provider experience (Table 1). A TJA practice should choose 236 which patients are appropriate for telemedicine based on practice philosophy, the needs of the 237 patient, and, during the current pandemic, the greater good of society. Neither the American 238 Association of Hip and Knee Surgeons nor the American Association of Orthopaedic Surgeons 239 has yet made recommendations regarding which patients would benefit from telemedicine versus in-person visits. [5] Such decisions may be based on data from other fields and determined 241 experientially.242Evidence supports the effectiveness of telemedicine for TJA patients. One study found 243 that orthopaedic surgeons reported that telemedicine, including telemedicine for TJA patients,244 was not inferior to standard clinic visits across the spectrum of visit types, from new 245 consultations through long-term follow-up. [12] The authors reported no significant difference in 246 duration of evaluation in telemedicine visits compared with in-person encounters but emphasized 247 the importance of having radiographs taken before the evaluation and available for remote 248 review. Importantly, their exclusion criteria for telemedicine visits included the inability to 249 provide informed consent, which can prevent the use of telemedicine for patients with advanced 250 cognitive dysfunction, incarcerated patients, patients who need an interpreter, and patients with 251 complex problems requiring extensive physical examination. Although the need for an 252 interpreter has been cited as a reason not to use telemedicine, current IT platforms and 253 telemedicine workflows allow the use of remote interpreter services, which expands the pool of 254 potentially eligible patients. 255 Consistent with recommendations made by Buvik et al [12], we have imaging readily 256 available when the physician or advanced practice provider meets the patient. This practice is 257 accomplished by having imaging completed prior to the scheduled appointment. For patients 258 who have had their imaging performed an imaging center that is unaffiliated with our institution, 259 a HIPAA-compliant cloud-based imaging application can allow for remote review of images. 260 Most telecommunications platforms have a "share-screen" function, so that imaging and 261 laboratory results can be reviewed with the patient in real time. Although data are scarce regarding telemedicine in TJA practice, evidence suggests that 263 telemedicine compares favorably with traditional clinic visits for TJA patients, including the 264 ability to examine patients via surrogate findings. Assessment of range of motion can be 265 effectively performed through telemedicine by selective questioning involving activities of daily 266 living such as sitting and rising from the toilet, the ability to don socks, or the ability to tie shoe 267 laces. [37] Additionally, Sharareh and Schwarzkopf [52] found that 33 postoperative TJA 268 patients seen through telemedicine had significantly higher satisfaction rates, fewer unscheduled 269 clinic visits, and fewer telephone calls to the office during the 90-day period after TJA compared 270 with 40 patients who were seen in traditional clinic visits. No postoperative adverse events 271 occurred in either the in-person or the telemedicine group during the 3-month study period. 272 Similar findings have been noted in other surgical and nonsurgical fields.

TABREF1.text: [51] Low levels of computer literacy and high patient expectations can lead to patient dissatisfaction with telemedicine encounters. Maintaining independence and autonomy are critical, particularly among elderly patients [35], so choosing an IT system that addresses these needs is essential. For organizations, effectiveness, efficiency, workflow, and implementation models are most often cited as considerations when implementing new technology. [51] Ultimately, when choosing a telemedicine platform for a TJA outpatient clinic, it is important to choose one that is simple and intuitive to use and easy to implement. It is vital to establish the goals and priorities of the outpatient telemedicine TJA clinic so that it can help care for patients during the COVID-19 pandemic while offering scalability to continue It is important to confirm the readiness and willingness of patients to use telemedicine technology because success depends on active patient participation. [33] Providers should review their patients' demographic characteristics. The review should include, among other factors, age, socioeconomic and insurance status, health literacy, dependence on a caregiver, distance to travel to attend appointments, and pertinent cultural aspects, such as language barriers. [23, 33, 45, 51] Elderly patients, in particular, may be apprehensive about computer-based services and concerned about privacy, so addressing these factors is imperative. [18] However, the desire for telemedicine among TJA patients is high, with approximately 70% of patients reporting that they are willing to use telemedicine for their care needs. [40]The COVID-19 pandemic is an extraordinary circumstance requiring immediate action to establish a telemedicine program. In an ideal situation, in which telemedicine can be phased in over a longer period, patient attitudes and technological abilities can be assessed through focus group discussions[31] and/or surveys. [25, 63]  The purpose of such tools is to determine patient desires and motivations for their care, experience with telemedicine and technology, and health literacy levels. Areas of focus include reasons patients come to the clinic, barriers to traveling to the clinic, patient comfort with and access to technology, patient experience and/or comfort with telemedicine, and patient comfort and trust with receiving instructions through digital are more likely to embrace telemedicine.[42, 51]  Quantitative and qualitative data can reveal areas where patient education and support are needed.
